author: TimeRemove
body:
Palantir catalog:   

 - CRM now with AI™ (Foundry).     
 - Microsoft Power BI with AI™ (Gotham).     
 - Cloud but with 100x marketing (Apollo).   

But companies license it because AI/ML is *so hot right now* and selling super advanced capabilities++ is way sexier than "Let's just license Power BI Premium w/Advanced AI, SQL Server, and Microsoft Dynamics from this little upstart called Microsoft."   

Half the posts about them here is "I don't really understand what they do." That isn't by accident, they literally make money by taking simple ideas, sprinkling in some AI/ML just *because*, and making them sound future-tech-ie.   

The people that understand PLTR skip it because even if they *could* become something eventually it is just a pile of buzzword snakeoil right now. Of course the USG paid money for it, getting the DoD to buy shit is practically an American tradition.

author: mscalaw96
body:
I work in data and analytics at a Media company and use Snowflake every day in my work.

I’m bullish on Snowflake because it is BY FAR, the best data warehousing product on the market by a mile. 

Most other data warehousing products out there cost a TON to use (look up teradata - they’ve struggled to grow revenue the past few years) - by cost a ton I’m meaning implementation fees alone can range in the millions of dollars, effectively locking anyone but the biggest of companies out from using their product.

Snowflake on the other hand is cheap. It’s not a SAAS product, you don’t pay subscription fees to use it. Instead, you purchase credits from snowflake (this is the $1.4B in future revenue that they already have booked), and consume these credits to run queries, import data etc into Snowflake. 

Using credits to do our day to day work explains why Snowflakes revenue retention rate is so high. Customers, like us, are constantly querying the data in our data warehouse to update business dashboards, pull reports etc. This data normally needs to be refreshed at least daily, if not multiple times a day. Every time a query is refreshed Snowflake makes money.

Given how easy it is to import data from a variety of sources, the number of business intelligence developers that we’ve employed has increased 5x because the business sees such value in a platform. No longer does it takes days or weeks to import data into Snowflake, you can have clean, transformed and ready to use data, pushing that into your business dashboards, in a matter of hours. As we move more reports away from being manual and done in excel to being automated and powered by Snowflake, our cost to use the product naturally increases over time.

The reason why I am bullish on Snowdlake is because there target market is SO LARGE. They have under 5000 customers WORLDWIDE, who use their product. For reference, the media company I work for is SMALL (i’m based in New Zealand), and we probably spend roughly 30k per year on Snowflake for all our data warehousing needs.

Think of mega cap companies, like Coca Cola, Walmart, Home Depot etc and think about the VOLUME of data that they have! Billions of rows of operational data that is ONLY INCREASING OVER TIME. Think of the number of disparate systems - CRM, accounting, billing, procurement etc, and think about the need for having this data in a place where analysts across a business can query one place for the business source of truth.

Think also about how the amount of data over time is only going to increase as become more of an interconnected world - IOT, more data being consumed over the internet, automated cars, robots - all are going to require that data to be stored somewhere and used at a later date - that’s what Snowflake does.

Literally, they could stop growing their customer numbers and their revenue would still grow 60%+ per year as their existing customers become more integrated with the warehouse and query it more and more.

From a technical perspective, sure they’re competing against the likes of Amazon, Microsoft and Google, but these products are SHIT compared to the godliness of Snowflake. Literally, the ability to query 320million rows of data in a query in Snowflake that takes 6 minutes to run vs 6 HOURS in Azure.

As a professional in the industry, I will not promote any product other than Snowflake to a future business that I work for if they don’t yet have a data warehouse. This is only going to amplify over time as the people using the product become the spokespeople for it - because Snowflake is THAT GOOD.

So yes, from an investment perspective, Snowflake is HELLA expensive. 60x TTM sales is ridiculous, regardless of the growth rate of the company. However, if you begin to consider the total number of customers that can use them (because their revenue is usage rather than subscription based, both large and small customers can easily use them -  no other product allows for this), the fact that data levels are only going to increase over time, and the fact that their product is clearly superior to everything else on the market, you can see why they are valued so richly.

TLDR: Snowflake user. Snowflake is dope asf. They have so many more people they can sell to and will see revenue growth rates for a long time to come. BUY

body:
EV and Space stocks kinda risky. If it were me i'd cut FSR and SPCE for something safer that pays a dividend or another index fund such as SPY/VOO/VTI to at least protect a larger portion of your portfolio in case growth comes under fire again.

If you must go all in growth. Maybe consider cloud stocks such as CRWD, SNOW, CRM or international ecommerce stocks such as CPNG, JMIA, and SE those have gotten beaten and could get hit if growth sells off again.

author: blackiechan25
body:
You're 18. What you have that not many of us have in Reddit is time. You've picked some pretty safe, slow growing companies, which there's nothing wrong with besides the fact that you'll be growing too slow for your age.

What young investors should do is invest more in growth oriented companies (I don't mean the SPACs or high risk growth companies of the world) because you can waiver the downturns in the market in the long run than let's say, someone in their 50s.

Your "risk adjusted" returns over 10 years via growth stocks will be well rewarded and as you get older, that's when you start shifting to less volatile names like your BAC, KO, MSFT of the world.

Example of what I mean for growth companies: Square (SQ), Draftkings (DKNG), Petco (WOOF), Salesforce (CRM), Spotify (SPOT)

#$PLTR..KNOW WHAT YOU OWN- Put F.U.D. on Ignore.

1) PLTR is an A.I. Data Mining Co. Just like Salesforce except it is growing at a quicker pace.

2) PLTR has two main Platforms, a) Gotham which serves U.S. Agencies, CIA, FBI, ICE and  the Military b) Foundry serves Commercial Businesses 

3) PLTR’s Gotham is the default operating  system for data across the U.S. Government.

4) PLTR generated 56% revenue from Government and 44% from Commercial customers in 2020

6) PLTR has new Contracts with the FDA,  The Army,  Air Force, Rio Tinto,  PG&E,  and DP.

author: fro2short
body:
sorry to keep replying to all your posts lol. you want to keep an eye on the DMAs, particularly the 50 DMA and 200 DMA as factors on top of the short term trend chart. 

and yeah actually that could be a situation where its worth it, more or less. If you didn't buy salesforce before it entered the Nasdaq, saw it jump 30% and then watched it bleed out all the gains over the next couple months, that could be a great stock to jump in because it may have been oversold into a correction by profit takers. 

i love salesforce but i took the profits as soon as it entered the NASDAQ for no other reason than 'wow it jumped 30% in one day im just taking my cash off the table and pocketing this' and never really looked back. that can create an inefficiency in the stock price

author: _sillycibin_
body:
PERI and CRSR absolutely killed it with their earnings and upped guidance and had enthusiastic forward looking statements.  Both dropped.  PERI was down 9% at one point.  I doubled down... but this market is cah-ray-zee.

I'd be careful of course with strategies that might be chasing the market's behavior.  Now that everything has dropped so much, we might actually see stocks go up on good earnings.  Look at Salesforce CRM, battered badly since it's recent high and it's still weeks away from reporting.  There are lots of macro concerns, but a lot of the sell off has been because we were at all time highs and there was sector rotation.  Well things have sold off, and the things rotated into have been pumped up...  Although if you're not crypto or a commodity or closely associated then no one cares about you.

author: GYN-k4H-Q3z-75B
body:
I don't want to crush the idea here nor have I done any real research into this, but as a developer who has worked for years in software consulting, mobile app development is considered a rather unattractive business.

Like web development, the entry bar is set very low because most apps are (or start out as) really simple. In this segment, you get low prices and you compete with tons of students, freelancers and local small businesses, all of which are perfectly capable of getting the job done. Being at a social occasion and hearing "I have an idea for an app" is a meme among programmers, and there are many who have built apps for local businesses. It does not scale up well.

With larger projects, most companies that have critical exposure to their customers via their apps either have de facto body leasing agreements with their preferred software consultancy or a standing in-house development team.

You may be able to find a software consultancy that does a lot of app development, but a pure play is unlikely. Often, mobile development is just a side show for them, and the real money is in ERP, CRM or custom enterprise development.

author: heapsp
body:
I'm also bullish on CVS, not for the same reasons as most people - they are in my opinion a data vendor. They are the best pharmacy at gathering datasets for big pharma to use in the US.

What many people don't realize is all healthcare data is controlled and sold in the US. You'd think when you go to a hospital, all of that information could be used (blinded) for research purposes - but there are data networks that SELL the data for huge sums from hospital networks. The same with pharmacies. If big Pharma wants to know where their competitors are selling the most and where their salesforce planning needs to happen - they buy CVS's prescription data.

author: bg1029camp
body: It's pretty obvious that all the entry-level Joe's in this thread don't have a clue about Salesforce or what they do. First, shitty implementation doesn't make a shitty product. Second, Salesforce is much more than their legacy CRM software anyways. It's now their 3rd largest product cloud and is not counted on to deliver the 20%+ Y/Y growth you continue to see every quarter (although it's still posting double digit growth). You are obviously free to spend your hard-earned dollars elsewhere, but CRM (the ticker) is going to keep posting high growth as they continue to gobble up market share and expand product offerings.

author: DonPietroSavastano88
body:
I refuse to sell. These leaps made up over 50% of my portfolio so to just eat the loss would of been too devastating. Instead, I decided to risk it all and double the fuck down lol. I sold every single position that I was still profitable in such as Apple, Salesforce, ect. I then used the money to purchase as many deep ITM NIO leaps as I could in order to bring my breakeven and average strike down. I snagged a 15c, 17c, and two 25c all expiring the same date as my original bleeding leaps (Jan 2023). 

I now have 90% of my portfolio in NIO which is absolutely insane but I was able to bring my breakeven price from $74 to under $55 which allows me to sleep a bit better lol.

author: dl_friend
body:
It's simply a matter of looking at each week's IV. For CRM expiration May 21, the IV is 32.56% - that's a base IV not affected by next week's earnings. The May 28 expiration IV is 54.89%. Notice that the IV is much larger because of the uncertainty caused by earnings.

The IV declines over the following weeks until by 45 dte, the IV is down to the mid-30s. It would be rare for an earnings event to affect IV beyond 60 dte.

author: andrwsc
body:
> Do you think in 10 years these will be the same stocks if you use the exact same metric? Of course you don't. So how will you adjust your portfolio? If you used the metric you used above to construct a portfolio for 2015, how many of the stocks you just listed above would be in your that portfolio?

This is an excellent question.  I went back to my spreadsheet and disregarded the returns from 2016-2020.  Here are the differences by sector:

* CHTR instead of GOOG
* WBA instead of TGT
* GILD and BIIB instead of DHR and TMO
* LMT and RTX instead of HON and UNP
* AVGO and CRM instead of AAPL and NVDA

So yeah, 8 of the 20 stocks would be different.  But you know what?  That portfolio still beat the S&P 500 in 4 of the 5 years from 2016-2020, with about 2x the total return.

author: TimeRemove
body:
Palantir catalog:   

 - CRM now with AI™ (Foundry).     
 - Microsoft Power BI with AI™ (Gotham).     
 - Cloud but with 100x marketing (Apollo).   

But companies license it because AI/ML is *so hot right now* and selling super advanced capabilities++ is way sexier than "Let's just license Power BI Premium w/Advanced AI, SQL Server, and Microsoft Dynamics from this little upstart called Microsoft."   

Half the posts about them here is "I don't really understand what they do." That isn't by accident, they literally make money by taking simple ideas, sprinkling in some AI/ML just *because*, and making them sound future-tech-ie.   

The people that understand PLTR skip it because even if they *could* become something eventually it is just a pile of buzzword snakeoil right now. Of course the USG paid money for it, getting the DoD to buy shit is practically an American tradition.

author: blackiechan25
body:
You're 18. What you have that not many of us have in Reddit is time. You've picked some pretty safe, slow growing companies, which there's nothing wrong with besides the fact that you'll be growing too slow for your age.

What young investors should do is invest more in growth oriented companies (I don't mean the SPACs or high risk growth companies of the world) because you can waiver the downturns in the market in the long run than let's say, someone in their 50s.

Your "risk adjusted" returns over 10 years via growth stocks will be well rewarded and as you get older, that's when you start shifting to less volatile names like your BAC, KO, MSFT of the world.

Example of what I mean for growth companies: Square (SQ), Draftkings (DKNG), Petco (WOOF), Salesforce (CRM), Spotify (SPOT)

author: junckdogg
body:
#$PLTR..KNOW WHAT YOU OWN- Put F.U.D. on Ignore.

1) PLTR is an A.I. Data Mining Co. Just like Salesforce except it is growing at a quicker pace.

2) PLTR has two main Platforms, a) Gotham which serves U.S. Agencies, CIA, FBI, ICE and  the Military b) Foundry serves Commercial Businesses 

3) PLTR’s Gotham is the default operating  system for data across the U.S. Government.

4) PLTR generated 56% revenue from Government and 44% from Commercial customers in 2020

5) PLTR  revenue growth for 2020 rose 47%... 77 % of that growth was from Government.

6) PLTR has new Contracts with the FDA,  The Army,  Air Force, Rio Tinto,  PG&E,  and DP.

PERI and CRSR absolutely killed it with their earnings and upped guidance and had enthusiastic forward looking statements.  Both dropped.  PERI was down 9% at one point.  I doubled down... but this market is cah-ray-zee.

I'd be careful of course with strategies that might be chasing the market's behavior.  Now that everything has dropped so much, we might actually see stocks go up on good earnings.  Look at Salesforce CRM, battered badly since it's recent high and it's still weeks away from reporting.  There are lots of macro concerns, but a lot of the sell off has been because we were at all time highs and there was sector rotation.  Well things have sold off, and the things rotated into have been pumped up...  Although if you're not crypto or a commodity or closely associated then no one cares about you.

author: GYN-k4H-Q3z-75B
body:
I don't want to crush the idea here nor have I done any real research into this, but as a developer who has worked for years in software consulting, mobile app development is considered a rather unattractive business.

Like web development, the entry bar is set very low because most apps are (or start out as) really simple. In this segment, you get low prices and you compete with tons of students, freelancers and local small businesses, all of which are perfectly capable of getting the job done. Being at a social occasion and hearing "I have an idea for an app" is a meme among programmers, and there are many who have built apps for local businesses. It does not scale up well.

With larger projects, most companies that have critical exposure to their customers via their apps either have de facto body leasing agreements with their preferred software consultancy or a standing in-house development team.

You may be able to find a software consultancy that does a lot of app development, but a pure play is unlikely. Often, mobile development is just a side show for them, and the real money is in ERP, CRM or custom enterprise development.

author: AnonBoboAnon
body:
I can’t think of any pure play companies but the closest parallels would be the cloud field. I know AWS and Azure have app services via a true app written in a true language or just low code like power apps and power bi. 

Even the chatbots in a lot of website are just imbedded cloud apps running on all of the NLP the providers have and you route the data points and logic in a GUI.

CRM is a basically this but a suite strictly for business services and accompanying utilities.

If someone really figure out a good way to offer this together and bring the fractured market together they’d crush it.

author: DonPietroSavastano88
body:
I originally had purchased three $40 calls with same expiration as yours when the stock price was at like $55 a share. I'm down over 75% on those right now lol. 

Last week, I decided to just sell everything i was still in the green with (apple, salesforce, etc) and just doubled-down on my Nio leaps by buying them mostly deep ITM. I did this so that I can bring my original breakeven price down. I bought two $25 calls, one $17 call, one $15 call, and two $55 calls. Before purchasing these, my breakeven was around $72. Now my breakeven is below 55 and I could certainly sleep better at night 😂. Still a bit risky but better than before. 

I can't speak for any of your other positions. But if you're in a similar spot as I was and you're starting to get nervous, then the approach I took is something to consider at least. For me, it was the obvious choice rather than selling for over 75% loss haha.

Before NIO's recent correction, $80 leaps expiring Jan 2023 seemed like a decent bet. Now, I feel like we will be extremely lucky to see $75 a share by that date. Obviously just my opinion though.

Good luck and stay strong, brotha !

author: PuffyPanda200
body:
Sorry if I wasn't clear, there are other companies that provide different tools that are seemingly similarly dominant in their industry (not data analysis).

A really good example would be Autodesk (ADSK). They make the AutoCad family, REVIT and other tools, all for construction design. They are very dominant in this field and it would be very difficult for competitors to break in for a variety of reasons. ADSK trades at a 52 P/E ratio and about 20 P/R ratio. I think they are a bit overvalued and Yahoo seems to agree with me. I wouldn't stay they are a bad buy though. This company is only valued at ~2 times PLTR but looks way better. Another example would be ANSYS (ANSS) that makes FEA software. 

PLTR provides what one would hope is a dominant data analysis suite/tools. That's great but I am just not sure that they will find enough customers that sit in the 'goldilocks zone' of having enough data to analyze and not having the resources to create the tools themselves. I am also not entirely certain that companies that run systems like CRM services can't provide similar tools with other items. Salesforce, Google, and Microsoft all advertise data analytics. How would a customer know if the Palantir tools are better or worse than those produced by other larger companies that the customer may already have a relationship with (CRM, Microsoft suite, G-suite, etc.)?

author: Barca1313
body: I think you’re missing my point. The software doesn’t decide anything. It’s like blaming Microsoft Excel and Salesforce for my company going bankrupt. Softwares don’t make decisions they simply analyze the data you give it and then you make the decision. The decisions to search for Bin Laden, go to war or deport immigrants were not made by any software. They were made by the people in our government. The people in our government could have just as well used the Palantir software for good, to make common sense immigration reform and use the data analytics in that way.

author: The_Folkhero
body: Don't get me wrong, I own Apple too, in equal weighting in my portfolio. But you hit upon it, % return wise there are better plays. Because isn't it % returns that we are chasing in stocks?! And I am willing, and have, been putting down a larger % on the smaller cap players.. That's why I am not overweight  Apple and am overweight smaller cap companies such as the "baby FAANGs of Adobe, Salesforce, Intuit, and especially, out of FAANG, Facebook (which is not even at a trillion market cap). The Apple trees don't grow to the sky and stock physics apply. And great companies don't always get bigger - just look at the dead money that Microsoft was for a decade. Cisco is another company that was one of the largest stocks back in the day and today it is a relic of what it once was.

author: sc8132217174
body:
This is so gerry-rigged, but we paid so much for sales force and I hate it. What I’ve liked a lot more is actually this little drag and drop app platform called glide run off of Google sheets. It’s so simple to make forms, add data items, checkboxes, etc. Not saying it’s in any way a replacement for big companies, but I can’t understand why they don’t make something that’s actually user friendly. I guess because then they can’t sell “architects”?

Also salesforce makes you pay with check. Which I think demonstrates how ridiculous they are.

When I personally invest, I buy stocks I’m willing to hold forever in case the trade goes bad.  I use MACD crossover and 7,15,50 day moving averages to determine when to get back into the stocks. author: Start155
body:
Major part of your comment history is either arguing with people about how great PLTR is and how Salesforce is a bad product, how Tableau is a garbage product etc. How PLTR is awesome because they have partnership with AWS and IBM. Seriously? go check how many companies have partnership with AWS that you never even heard of. It's like someone selling something in Amazon and telling people he has a partnership with Amazon. And how are you getting this random number that he will need to pay over $500,000,000? Did he tell you that or did you ever see his tax filling? Based on the vesting schedule of 2.5% per quarter there will be a total of 10.95M stocks from options and RSUs combined by the end of this year that he might need to pay tax on. Overestimating the average price per share at $23 will results in a net compensation from these equities at $251M. Even if he pay full 40% tax on that compensation that will be 100M at max which is fully deductible against expenses. 

You have a conclusion based on your hope that Palantir will do good on some days so that you can offload your large bag and that's why you keep arguing with random stranger all over the reddit for Palantir. 

Hope is good but delusion is a prime cause for bag holder. Delusion like justifying premature selling of large quantity share by a CEO within six of going public when the company is still bleeding money by saying he will need to pay tax as if he is the only CEO in this tech world who pays tax and no one else pay anything. The whole world knows how unfair the tax rule is for CEOs compare to mass population where the CEOs can completely write of the whole tax liability from the performance based stock compensation which is the major part of their overall package. 

Get out of your delusion.
